summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's third motion for release on bail pending trial. The order details the court's reasoning, reaffirming that Maxwell poses a significant flight risk due to her substantial international ties, financial resources, and lack of candor, and that no combination of proposed conditions, including renouncing citizenship and asset monitoring, can reasonably assure her appearance.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, indicted on charges related to sex trafficking of minors and perjury. She is seeking release on bail for a third time.

persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who authored this order denying Maxwell's third bail motion.

connections.description: Judge-defendant relationship. Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and ruling on her bail motions.

events.title: Initial Bail Hearing and Detention Order
events.description: The court held a bail hearing and concluded Maxwell was a clear flight risk, denying bail and ordering her detained at the Metropolitan Detention Center.

events.title: Second Bail Motion Filed
events.description: Maxwell filed a renewed motion for release on bail, which was denied by the court on December 28, 2020.

events.title: Third Bail Motion Filed
events.description: Maxwell filed her third motion for release on bail, proposing new conditions including renouncing citizenship and asset monitoring.

events.title: Third Bail Motion Denied
events.description: Judge Nathan issued this order denying Maxwell's third motion for bail, concluding the new proposals did not mitigate the flight risk.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was indicted on charges of conspiracy to entice minors, transporting minors for illegal sex acts, and perjury.

The court has repeatedly denied bail, finding Maxwell a significant flight risk due to her international ties (French and British citizenship), substantial financial resources, and lack of candor about her assets.
Maxwell's third bail proposal included renouncing her French and British citizenship and having a retired federal judge monitor her and her spouse's assets.

The court found considerable legal uncertainty about whether renouncing citizenship would prevent France from refusing extradition, as nationality may be assessed at the time the offense was committed.
The court determined that even with the proposed asset monitor, Maxwell would retain access to substantial funds (e.g., $450,000 for living expenses) sufficient to facilitate flight.
